results.title: Reinforcement in learning and extinction
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and Herbert Kerkow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Shows how learning is reinforced through stimulus-responses and extinguished when not reinforced, but rapidly reacquired when once more reinforced. Pigeons are used to demonstrate this learning process through responding through such stimuli as a hole in the wall, food, buzzer, and light. Removal of rewards makes them “forget” and return of reward reintroduces the learning almost immediately.

group_siblings.title: Perception
group_siblings.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow Productions and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Perception
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow Productions and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
This film presents the theory that perception is not merely the sensing of stimuli but is a set of elaborate processes through which we organise our sensory impressions into meaningful pictures of the objects and events around us. The basic principles that support the theory are illustrated by the activities of a group of students relaxing in a common room.

results.title: Learning discriminations and skills
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
In an analysis of the learning process, this film demonstrates that the learning of a skill by any organism involves two basic and integrated processes: discrimination between stimuli and application of this discrimination in the making of selected responses. Laboratory experiments with pigeons are used in the demonstration.

results.title: Development of individual differences
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Presents the thesis that though heredity sets certain limits to the development of an individual, environment, which includes everything that happens to an individual, is of great importance. Shows how Tommy and Jimmy Bradley develop different personalities since their environments are not really similar, social expectancy pushing one toward one side of the family, the other toward the other side. Reaction of the two brothers to a new neighbour and different family life are shown.

results.title: Controlling behavior through reinforcement
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Schedules of conditioning thorugh reinforcement are illustrated with pigeons in Skinner apparatus and their applications to human behaviour are indicated. Demonstrates the effects of: (1) fixed rate reinforcement which results in a high work output; (2) variable intervals resulting in the falling off of output; (3) variable interval reinforcement which causes continuous output at a high rate and persists after reinforcement discontinues.

results.title: Conflict
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Descriptions and illustrations of the four classes of motivational conflict (after Dollard and Millar) are shown, demonstrating the basic research on animals and then generalising this into an understanding of human behaviour. Laboratory animals (rats, in this case) in a typical T-maze experiment point out the principles used in analysing and interpreting the behaviour of high school and university students.

results.title: Common fallacies about group differences
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
A painter working in a classroom makes a statement about the French race and Latin temperament. A professor, over-hearing his remark, tries to correct his misconceptions. Among other facts, he points out that a nation is not a race, that members of a group are never “all anything”, that group behaviour cannot be judged by isolated cases.

results.title: The Brain and behavior
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology”.
Demonstrates two ways in which the function of different brain areas can be studied. One method is to stimulate different parts of the living brain with an electrode. The other is to measure the changes in behaviour following injuries to different areas of the brain.

group_works.title: Conservation tillage protecting our greatest asset

results.title: Conservation tillage protecting our greatest asset
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Protecting Our Greatest Asset”.
It should be noted that this video is made by a chemical company that manufactures herbicides. Intensive cropping and continual cultivation stresses the Australian soil dramatically. This video looks at alternative methods to soil tillage by machinery, namely herbicides. Crops which require no tillage as conservation are also discussed.
